'''Opera Solutions, LLC''' is a technology and [[analytics]] company mainly focused on capturing profit growth opportunities emerging from [[big data]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://feedroom.businessweek.com/?fr_story=bb41c1f9e1fdf96cc2d371569c96b69cb189bf59|title=Maximizing Return from Data|date=September 29, 2009|accessdate=August 6, 2010|work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]}}</ref> The firm uses a combination of medical learning science, advanced predictive analytics,[[technology]], large-scale [[data management]], and human expertise<ref name=InfoManagement>{{cite web|first=David|last=Menninger|url=http://www.information-management.com/blogs/predictive_analytics_Opera_big_data_SaaS-10020994-1.html|title=Opera Solutions Adds Science to Predictive Analytics|date=August 23, 2011|accessdate=September 1, 2011|work=Information Management}}</ref> to build and deliver analytics solutions to large and mid-sized clients in a number of sectors,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/managing/content/sep2009/ca20090929_866063.htm|title=What We Can Learn from Netflix|date=September 29, 2009|accessdate=August 6, 2010|work=[[Bloomberg Businessweek]]}}</ref> including [[financial services]], [[health-care]], [[capital markets]], [[insurance]], [[consumer goods]], [[retail]], [[manufacturing]], [[distribution (business)|distribution]], and [[government]]. Opera Solutions delivers [[predictive analytics]] as a service, and offers a number of hosted, cloud-based solutions focused on solving specific business problems, e.g., predicting the behavior of individual consumers, stopping revenue leakage in hospitals, warning of threats to corporate security or brand health, etc. The company also works with a limited number of very large clients to create and deliver more highly customized solutions. <ref name="InfoManagement"/>
==Company== Established in 2004 by CEO [[Arnab Gupta]], the firm has 700 employees from over 30 countries,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://techcrunch.com/2011/09/14/big-data-analytics-company-opera-solutions-raises-84m-in-first-round-funding//|title=Big Data Analytics Company Opera Solutions Raises $84M in First-Round Funding|date=September 14, 2011|accessdate=October 28, 2011|work=TechCrunch}}</ref> including 200 advanced-degree, award winning scientists.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lopez|first=Isacc|title=Big Data Big Five|url=http://www.datanami.com/datanami/2013-05-24/big_data_big_five.html|publisher=Datanami}}</ref> Opera is headquartered in the [[New York metropolitan area|New York/New Jersey metro area]] with offices in [[Jersey City, New Jersey|Jersey City]], [[New York City|New York]], [[London]], [[Boston]], [[San Diego]], [[Shanghai]], and [[New Delhi]]. It is ranked as a top 10 big data vendor that derives 100% of its revenue from big data products and services. As of January, 2012, the company was valued around $500 million.<ref>{{cite web|last=Berman|first=Dennis|title=So, What's Your Algorithm?|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052970203462304577138961342097348.html|publisher=WSJ}}</ref>
==Funding== On September 14, 2011, Opera Solutions announced that it had raised $84 million <ref>{{cite web|url=http://venturebeat.com/2011/09/14/opera-solutions-84-million-round/|title=Data Analytics firm Opera Solutions closes $84M round|date=September 14, 2011|accessdate=October 28, 2011|work=VentureBeat}}</ref> in capital that the company says it will use to build and expand their engineering and sales force.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424053111903532804576569133957145822.html|title='Big Data' Firm Raises $84 Million|date=September 14, 2011|accessdate=October 28, 2011|work=The Wall Street Journal}}</ref> The round was led by Silver Lake Sumeru, with participation from Accel-KKR, Invus Financial Advisors, JGE Capital Management, and Tola Capital.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13846_3-20107545-62/opera-solutions-nabs-$84m-for-big-data-analytics/|title=Opera Solutions nabs $84M for 'Big Data' Analytics|date=September 14, 2011|accessdate=October 28, 2011|work=CNET}}</ref> In May 2013, Indian outsourcing-service company, Wipro Ltd., agreed to acquire a minority stake in Opera Solutions LLC for $30 million.<ref>{{cite web|last=Thoppil|first=Dhanya|title=Wipro to Buy Stake in U.S. Data-Services Firm|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424127887323372504578468962076579562.html|publisher=WSJ}}</ref>
==Netflix Prize== In 2009 Opera participated in the [[Netflix Prize]], a three-year-long analytics competition sponsored by the U.S. online [[movie rental]] company [[Netflix]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wired.com/epicenter/2009/08/netflix-prize-continues/|title=Netflix Prize: It Ain’t Over ’til It’s Over|date=August 12, 2009|accessdate=August 6, 2010|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]}}</ref> Opera was part of "The Ensemble", a three-team consortium that finished second, with model performance [[Netflix_Prize#2009|tied with the winner]]. The contest attracted 41,000 teams from 186 countries.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2009/09/21/winning-netflix-team-draws-from-att-yahoo/|title=Winning Netflix Team Draws From AT&T, Yahoo|date=September 21, 2009|accessdate=August 6, 2010|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | first=Marisa | last=Taylor}}</ref>
==KDD Cup== In 2012 Opera entered the KDD Cup, a well known data-mining competition that attracts industry leaders around the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kddcup2012.org/|publisher=KDD Cup}}</ref> Competing against 170 teams, Team Opera Solutions won second place in the Track 2 contest.<ref>{{cite web|title=Leaderboard 2012|url=http://www.kddcup2012.org/c/kddcup2012-track2/leaderboard|publisher=KDD Cup}}</ref>
==Heritage Health Prize== In 2013 Opera participated in the Heritage Health Prize Competition, a two year national contest for developers to create breakthrough techniques to improve America’s health care system.<ref>{{cite web|title=Heritage Provider Network Health Prize|url=http://www.heritagehealthprize.com/c/hhp|publisher=Heritage Health}}</ref> Team Opera Solutions is ranked top 5 five out of 1659 participants.<ref>{{cite web|title=Public Leaderboard|url=http://www.heritagehealthprize.com/c/hhp/leaderboard|publisher=Heritage Health}}</ref>
==Industry Recognition== Gartner, Inc. recognized Opera Solutions in their Cool Vendors in Analytics, 2013 Report.<ref>{{cite web|last=Herschel|first=Gareth|title=Cool Vendors in Analytics|url=http://www.gartner.com/DisplayDocument?doc_cd=250345&ref=g_noreg|publisher=Gartner}}</ref> [[IDG’s Computerworld Honors Program]] recognized Opera Solutions Government Services (OSGS) as one of its 2013 Laureates. <ref>{{cite web|title=The Computerworld Honors Program Names 267 Laureates Using IT to Drive Business and Social Change|url=http://www.idgenterprise.com/press/the-computerworld-honors-program-names-268-laureates-using-it-to-drive-business-and-social-change|publisher=IDG Enterprise}}</ref> [[ESG Global]] named Opera Solutions as a finalist for Big Data Vendor of the Year for 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ingest to Insight Big Data Vendor of the Year 2012 and 2013 Outlook: Finalists – Cloudera, IBM Opera Solutions|url=http://www.esg-global.com/blogs/ingest-to-insight-big-data-vendor-of-the-year-2012-and-2013-outlook-finalists-cloudera-ibm-opera-solutions/?utm_campaign=Opera%20Solutions%20Named%20a%20Gartner%20Cool%20Vendor%20in%20Analytics%20for%20201305082013&utm_sourc|publisher=ESG Global}}</ref> Opera Solutions was also recognized as a top 100 Big Data social media influencer by [[Big Data Republic]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Sherry|first=Saul|title=The PeerIndex #BigData100 Announced!|url=http://www.bigdatarepublic.com/author.asp?section_id=2642&doc_id=262105}}</ref>
==Big Data Discourse Series== In April 2011, Opera Solutions began what it calls the "Big Data Discourse Series," a series of discussion events with private sector and government leaders focused on the societal and business impact of Big Data.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/08/idUS186378+08-Apr-2011+PRN20110408|title=Opera Solutions and Newark Mayor Cory Booker Host Discussion on the Promise of Technology and Open Data in Government|date=April 8, 2011|accessdate=September 1, 2011|work=[[Reuters]]}}</ref> To date, the series has featured [[Newark, New Jersey]] Mayor [[Cory Booker]]<ref name=TIME>{{cite web|first=Feifei|last=Sun|url=http://newsfeed.time.com/2011/04/07/5-questions-with-twitter-savvy-newark-mayor-cory-booker/|title=5 Questions with Twitter-Savvy Newark Mayor Cory Booker|date=April 6, 2011|accessdate=September 1, 2011|work=TIME}}</ref><ref name=CapitalNY>{{cite web|first=Gillian|last=Reagan|url=http://www.capitalnewyork.com/article/culture/2011/04/1780392/cory-booker-pitches-newark-startup-new-york-tech-elite|title=Cory Booker pitches Newark as a 'startup' to New York tech scene|date=April 6, 2011|accessdate=September 1, 2011|work=Capital New York}}</ref> and [[Michael Chertoff]],<ref name=WSJ1>{{cite web|first=Jennifer|last=Valentino-DeVries|url=http://blogs.wsj.com/digits/2011/06/23/chertoff-rules-and-regulations-complicate-anti-cybercrime-efforts/|title=Chertoff: ‘Rules and Regulations’ Complicate Anti-Cybercrime Efforts|date=June 23, 2011|accessdate=September 1, 2011|work=Wall Street Journal}}</ref><ref name=CNNMoney>{{cite web|first=David|last=Goldman|url=http://money.cnn.com/2011/07/28/technology/government_hackers/index.htm|title=China vs. U.S.: The cyber Cold War is raging|date=July 28, 2011|accessdate=September 1, 2011|work=CNNMoney}}</ref> the former head of the [[United States Department of Homeland Security]] under [[George W. Bush]], as keynote speakers.
